title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" establishes a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. It also addresses applicable laws, requirements, and the availability of funds for the self-determination process. The Congress acknowledges past presidential actions regarding Puerto Rico's political status, including the establishment of a task force to identify options for the territory's future status. President George W. Bush amended the executive order to require regular reports on progress. President George W. Bush's Executive Order 13183 required regular reports on Puerto Rico's status. A task force appointed by Bush recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to choose between remaining a territory or pursuing a nonterritorial status. If Puerto Rico elects a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should hold a plebiscite for the people to choose between two options. If Puerto Rico remains a territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to keep Congress informed of the people's wishes. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite for voters to choose between continuing territorial status or pursuing a nonterritorial status. If the majority favors continued territorial status, additional plebiscites will be held every 8 years. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years if the majority vote favors continued territorial status. If the majority votes for permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be held with options for statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. The plebiscite in Puerto Rico offers two options: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. If a majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite must be held by the 111th Congress, but no later than December 31, 2009. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, another plebiscite must be held within 2 years after the certification of the majority vote. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. All Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite held under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules for the plebiscites. Eligible voters include those under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and U.S. citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet the Commission's requirements. In any plebiscite held under this Act, eligible voters include all voters under Puerto Rico's electoral laws and U.S. citizens born in Puerto Rico who meet the Commission's requirements. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will certify the results to the President and Congress. The President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report to Congress within 6 months after the plebiscite provided for in section 3(c). After the plebiscite, the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status will submit a report to Congress within 6 months, detailing measures for implementing the chosen nonterritorial status option. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all required plebiscites are completed, up to $5,000,000 from funds allocated to Puerto Rico may be used by the State Elections Commission for plebiscite expenses, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status.
